id< Startainer > owner
 The object which is using the receiver to store its Starks.
NSString * browfileIdentifier
 The -identifier of the receiver's -owner, or an empty string if the receiver's -owner does not respond to -browfile.

Detailed Description

Instantiated with a managed object context with Starks in it, Starker can do many of the common manipulations you need done on those Starks.

This object is used in three situations: as either the starker or the localStarker for an Extore, or the -managedObjectContext of a BmxBk document. This class was written because the three situations described all require some common methods for accessing Starks and collections of Starks.

The receiver's managed object context may contain other objects besides Starks.

I wanted to mke this a subclass of NSManagedObjectContext. However, the documentation for NSManagedObjectContext says that "you are highly discouraged from subclassing" it. So, what I did instead was to make this class be a wrapper around an managed object context which is an instance variable. I also implemented message forwarding of unknown messages to the moc instance variable. I'm not sure whether that message forwarding is necessary or not.

Member Function Documentation

- (NSArray *) allSeparatorStarks  

Returns all starks in the receiver's managed object context for which -starypeValue returns StarypeSeparator.

- (NSArray *) allSoftStarks  

Returns all starks in the receiver's managed object context that are not fixture containers; return NO to -starypeIsFixture.

- (void) deleteAllStarks  

Delete all of the starks in the receiver's managed object context.￼.

￼ According to http://www.cocoabuilder.com/archive/message/cocoa/2006/11/15/174531, the Great mmalc seemed to think it was better, albeit slower, to delete all objects in the store, rather than replacing the store file. Actually, this is not possible in the general case anyhow, when the store may include other Starker's Starks or other entities.

- (void) deleteStarks: (id)  starks  

Delete a subset of the receiver's starks.￼.

Parameters:
starks May be either an NSArray* or NSSet*.

- (id) initWithManagedObjectContext: (NSManagedObjectContext*)  managedObjectContext_
owner: (id <Startainer>)  owner_ 

Designated Initializer for Starker instances ￼.

Both arguments are required. If either is nil, this method will return nil.

Parameters:
managedObjectContext See class properties for documentation.
owner See class properties for documentation.
Returns:
￼The receiver, or nil if something failed.

- (void) insertStarkInExtoreLikeStark: (Stark*)  otherStark  

￼

￼This method does not work yet

Parameters:
otherStark 

- (Stark *) newStark  

Inserts a new stark into receiver's managed object context and sets its browfileIdentifier to that of the receiver.

Returns:
The newly-inserted stark

- (Stark *) ohared  

Returns the receiver's Ohared (OmniWeb Shared) fixture collection, or nil if the receiver does not have one.

This fixture collection is nil for most Extores.

- (BOOL) refreshStarkCache  

Reads all starks from Core Data store into the ivar _starkCache.

This is often necessary for efficiency, to reduce the number of expensive fetches. See http://www.cocoabuilder.com/archive/message/cocoa/2005/10/20/148457

Returns:
If successful, returns YES. Otherwise, returns NO. Will return NO if the app's managed object context could not be created, which might happen if the app's Core Data store is down-versioned, could not be "migrated", and user clicked "Cancel" when given the opportunity to "Move" the store to the desktop and start a new one.

- (Stark *) root  

Returns the receiver's root Stark.

Returns the first of the receiver's Starks which has Starype value of StarypeRoot. However, there should be at most one of these, "the" root.

Returns:
The receiver's root stark, or nil if there is no root stark (which had better mean that the receiver's moc has no starks at all).

- (BOOL) save: (NSError**)  error  

Sends -save: to the receiver's managed object context.

￼Actually, the implementation of this method should not be necessary since message forwarding should cover it.

- (void) setRoot: (Stark*)  newRoot  

Deletes old root, if there is one, and sets the starype of the argument to be StarypeRoot.

The brief description literally explains all that this method does. That should be enough to make the argument take over as the new root Stark in the receiver's managed object context. Also, in the data model, in Stark_entity, I have set the Delete Rule on the childrenUnsorted relationship to Cascade. Therefore, I hope, deleting the old root will cause all of its descendants to also be deleted.

Parameters:
newRoot A stark which has previously been inserted into the receiver's managed object context

- (NSArray *) starksWithPredicate: (NSPredicate*)  predicate  

Gets all of the starks in the receiver's managed object context satisfying a given predicate, if any.

Pass predicate = nil to get all starks related to this extore.

Parameters:
predicate The predicate required of results, or nil.
Returns:
An array of results, or an empty array if no results are found

- (NSArray *) starksWithSubpredicates: (NSArray*)  subpredicates
type: (NSCompoundPredicateType)  type 

Returns all starks in the receiver's managed object context satisfying given predicates, if any, compounded OR or AND.

Parameters:
subpredicates The array of subpredicates to be compounded
type Either NSAndPredicateType or NSOrPredicateType
Returns:
An array of results, or an empty array if no results are found

- (Stark *) starkWithIdentifier: (NSString*)  externalIdentifier
createIfNotFound: (BOOL)  createIfNotFound 

Fetches, or optionally creates if needed, a stark from the receiver's managed object context with a given externalIdentifier.

The fetch is done first. If a stark with the desired externalIdentifier is not found in the receiver's managed object context and iscreateIfNotFound is YES, creates and inserts a new stark using -newStark.

Parameters:
externalIdentifier The externalIdentifier that is required of the result
createIfNotFound Whether or not to create a new stark if the fetch operation does not find a stark with externalIdentifier
Returns:
The fetched stark, a new stark, or nil if none was found and createIfNotFound was NO

- (Stark *) starkWithPredicate: (NSPredicate*)  predicate  

Same as -starksWithPredicate, but only returns the first item found.

Returns nil if no results are found

- (Stark *) starkWithSameURLAsStark: (Stark*)  stark  

Returns the first of the receiver's Starks which has a URL the same as a given Stark argument￼.

Typically, the Stark argument will belong to a different managed object context. This method is thus used to find corresponding or matching Starks in different managed object contexts.

- (Stark *) unfiled  

Returns the receiver's Bookmarks Unfiled fixture collection, or nil if the receiver does not have one.

This fixture collection is nil for most Extores.

Property Documentation

- (NSString *) browfileIdentifier [read, retain]

The -identifier of the receiver's -owner, or an empty string if the receiver's -owner does not respond to -browfile.

I had previously used this to filter starks in general; however at this time it is not used.

- (id< Startainer >) owner [read, write, retain]

The object which is using the receiver to store its Starks.

- (NSMutableDictionary *) starkCache [read, write, retain]

An NSMutableArray which, after refreshing, contains all of the Starks in the receiver's managed object context.

￼ I'm not sure if I'm going to use this or not.
